Q&A

Q:

What does a diversity visa entitle me to? Will the U.S. government help me find work?

A:

If you are issued a diversity visa (DV), you can live and work in the United States. The U.S. government will not pay for your airfare, find you a place to live or find you work. You will have to prove that you are unlikely to become dependent on the U.S. government for your living expenses. There is no specific amount of money you must prove you have. The consular officer will consider the totality of your circumstances during your visa interview.

Q:

Why isn’t my country eligible for this year’s DV program?

A:

Countries that have had more than 50,000 immigrants to the United States in the last five years are ineligible for the DV lottery. Although the ineligible countries are not permanently ineligible, we cannot speculate as to when they will again be eligible.

Q:

If I register for the DV program as the principal applicant, can my wife make a separate application as the principal applicant? Could this cause our applications to be disqualified?

A:

A husband and wife may each submit one entry if each meets the eligibility requirements. If either spouse is selected, the other may apply as a derivative dependent.

Q:

Can I apply for a diversity visa if I already hold a U.S. visa?

A:

Yes, you can apply for DV-2018 even if you already hold a U.S. visa.

Q:

Is it possible to change the address on my application if I’m selected but have since moved?

A:

If you are selected and need to change your address, contact us.

Q:

Why do you run out of diversity visas for people who were selected in the lottery?

A:

There are 50,000 DVs available for DV-2018. More than 50,000 people are selected in the lottery because some people selected don’t qualify for the visa or don’t pursue the visa, and USCIS wants to make sure all 50,000 visas are issued. Only the first qualified 50,000 applicants will be issued visas. After those visas are all issued, the program will end. If you wish to receive your visa, you must act promptly when selected. If you miss or reschedule your appointment or come without the required documentation, you risk a visa being unavailable.

Q:

If I win, what are the next steps?

A:

If you are selected for further processing in the Diversity Visa program, you will need to demonstrate you are eligible for a diversity immigrant visa by successfully completing the next steps. When requested to do so by the Kentucky Consular Center, you will need to complete the immigrant visa application, submit required documents and forms, pay required fees, complete a medical examination, and be interviewed by a consular officer at the U.S. embassy or consulate to demonstrate you qualify for a diversity visa.
